Award.AwardTitle: AGEP-BPR: A Study of the Cultural Factors Affecting Underrepresented Minority STEM Doctoral Students and Academic Pathway and Transition Programs

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Education and Human Resources

Award.AbstractNarration:
This project is supported by the Alliances for Graduate Education and the Professoriate (AGEP) program and is a Broadening Participation Research in STEM Education (AGEP-BPR) award. The AGEP-BPR awards target investigator initiated empirical research projects that seek to study theory-driven models and innovations related to the participation and success of underrepresented minorities (URMs) in STEM graduate education, postdoctoral training, and academic STEM careers at all types of institutions of higher education. This award funds a qualitative research study to advance foundational knowledge about the extent to which bridging and pathways programs for doctoral STEM students impact cultural change within underrepresented minority students and their universities, and how the cultural contexts relate to student retention and successful pursuit of doctoral degrees. The results of this investigation are expected to inform the field about future research, both basic and applied, that will increase the understanding of the barriers, practices and policies URM doctoral students experience when they participate in academic STEM bridge programs that are designed to increase student retention and degree completion. Findings will also inform university administrators, faculty, staff and students, as well as the public about the key features of programs intersecting with the cultural contexts in which the pathway programs operate; and such information has the potential to ultimately improve the experiences, retention and successes of URM STEM doctoral students in our nation?s schools.

The researchers conducting this study will explore the following questions: What criteria are STEM doctoral pathway programs using to recruit and admit URM students? What interventions or supports do STEM doctoral pathway programs use to promote URM students' social and academic preparation and integration for success in STEM doctoral programs? What cultural factors of the STEM department and the larger institution affect URM students' experiences in the doctoral pathway programs? Basing their work on Tierney's model of higher education organizational culture, the investigators will use document reviews, interviews with administrators, faculty, staff and students, and observation techniques to gather a collection of qualitative data to analyze and interpret to address the research questions. There is an external evaluator and a group of external advisory board members who will work together to provide formative and summative project assessment. Products are expected to include publications in peer-reviewed journals.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The American Institutes for Research (AIR) Study of the Cultural Factors Affecting Underrepresented Minority STEM Doctoral Students and Academic Pathway and Transition Programs was supported by an Alliances for Graduate Education and the Professoriate Broadening Participation Research (AGEP-BPR) grant (No. 1433835) from the National Science Foundation (NSF). The study’s purpose was to explore the key features of intended to increase the numbers of traditionally underrepresented minority (URM) students in science, technology, engineering, and mathematics (STEM) graduate programs. Specifically, this 3-year study aimed to explore the activities and strategies used by a sample of four pathways to doctorate programs (“bridge programs”) to increase the number of minoritized students’ earning STEM Ph.D.s. This exploratory, qualitative study was guided by three research questions:

  1. What criteria are bridge programs using to recruit and admit students?
  2. What interventions or supports do bridge programs use to promote students’ social and academic preparation and integration for success in STEM doctorate programs?
  3. What cultural factors of the STEM department and the larger institution affect students’ experiences in the bridge programs?

Within- and cross-case analyses of case study data collected from four bridge programs served as the central component of the research. Significant results of these analyses include the following:

  • Bridge program activities and student supports generally fell into four major categories: basic needs, academic, social, and social-emotional. The programs addressed students’ basic needs by providing tuition and financial support and helping students find housing and access health services. The programs supported students’ academic needs through high-touch mentoring and academic services such as tutoring and mandatory study sessions. Bridge activities and supports were designed to develop students’ self-efficacy as scientists and sense of belonging in their fields of study. Bridge programs used the “safe” space they created to simultaneously promote a culture of diversity and inclusion, while at the same time socialize students into the expectations and norms of STEM graduate programs—revealing a key tension between challenging the status quo and preparing students to survive and thrive within an often hostile STEM culture.
  • Bridge programs were beginning to alter some of the norms and assumptions of the traditional STEM culture in ways that promoted diversity and inclusion. They did this through challenging the sink-or-swim model and admissions procedures. The bridge programs brought attention to the idea that students do not bear full responsibility for their success in graduate school; rather, the program shares equal responsibility for students’ persistence and degree attainment. Bridge programs embodied this through proactive academic supports and monitoring, provided by all sites, whether in the form of mandatory study sessions, weekly check-ins with the program leaders on coursework and research, or the creation of an individual development plan. Some of the programming for bridge students were adopted department-wide for all graduate students. The inclusive nature of the bridge programs also elevated conversations about the value of placing less weight on GRE scores and giving more credence to assets such as self-determination, ability to overcome hardships, and intellectual risk-taking.
  • Creating and sustaining cultural change was a difficult and iterative process. STEM graduate programs have long been grounded in a meritocratic lens of what constitutes success, and any deviation from that standard is not met without challenge. Bridge programs struggled against being viewed as the primary mechanism for increasing underrepresented minority participation and success; responsibility for diversity and inclusion was shifted away from the STEM departments themselves, hindering departmentwide investments in diversity and broader cultural change.
  • Program leaders serve as important institutional agents in building minoritized students’ social capital and as key drivers of larger cultural change. Bridge program leaders facilitated conversations with STEM departments, challenging faculty to revisit norms and to implement new practices. However, program leaders’ efforts to both support students and to promote culture and policy change on their campuses required trade-offs and negotiations of their time and career trajectory.

The results of this study can support the development of programs and programmatic changes that can lead to more historically minoritized students’ accessing and experiencing success in their postsecondary STEM pursuits. In addition, our exploration of the cultural factors at the institutional and departmental levels deepens knowledge of where and how bridge programs are positioned on their campuses, the roles they play in promoting diverse and inclusive practices in STEM graduate program, and the experiences of the students these programs aim to serve. The study’s findings also can help institutional leaders better direct time and resources to ensure programming and supports for minoritized students are most effective and best integrated into the institution’s mission and strategic plan.
